content:
Thunderbird downloads the settings for and @gmail address from here https://autoconfig.thunderbird.net/v1.1/google.com

If it can not connect to that address it indicated you have networking issues on your apple product. Quite possible caused by a VPN. Some of them make a complete hash of anything that is not a web browser downloading a web page. Otherwise we generally look for antivurs products and their ubiquitous software firewalls, but you say you have already addressed that possible vector. but are you using some sort of locked down corporate DNS server that only contains local addresses or some such.

Seriously it is about 99.99% probably that your issue is not Thunderbird or any of it's settings.

content: Local Folders cannot be synchronized. To share my Local Folders between a TB 128 and a Thunderbird-Beta profile I put my Local Folders on iCloud Drive > Documents. Then in one TB version after the other I open Account Settings > Local Folders > Message Storage > Local Directory > button "Browse..." navigate to the new directory of my Local Folders on iCloud Drive, select "Local Folders" and click "Open". You have to restart TB to confirm the modification.

content:
tl;dr: check if anything is using port 8080 then stop that process

I also confirmed that my firewall is not interfering with the login process.

However, it turns out thunderbird requires a certain port (i suspect 8080) to be open and I have a few podman containers running on the same machine that interfered with the port thunderbird is using. After stopping all the podman containers I am able to login normally.

content:
Conseguimos pela seguinte solução: Kavya O Assistente Godaddy:

Para adicionar seu e-mail do Microsoft 365 ao Thunderbird no Mac e no Windows PC, siga estas etapas:

Abra o Thunderbird. Se você for um novo usuário, prossiga para a etapa 5. Caso contrário, no canto inferior esquerdo, selecione Configurações da conta. Selecione Ações da conta e Adicionar conta de e-mail. Digite seu nome completo e endereço de e-mail e selecione Continuar. Se as configurações do seu servidor forem detectadas, elas serão preenchidas automaticamente. Selecione Concluído e pule para a etapa 9. Caso contrário, continue para a próxima etapa. Em SERVIDOR DE ENTRADA, certifique-se de que os campos sejam os seguintes: Protocolo: IMAP Nome do host: outlook.office365.com Porta: 993 Segurança da conexão: SSL/TLS Método de autenticação: OAuth2 Nome de usuário: seu endereço de e-mail (por exemplo, jane@coolexample.com) Em SERVIDOR DE SAÍDA, certifique-se de que os campos sejam os seguintes: Nome do host: smtp.office365.com Porta: 587 Segurança da conexão: STARTTLS Método de autenticação: OAuth2 Nome de usuário: seu endereço de e-mail (por exemplo, jane@coolexample.com) Se for solicitado a conceder permissões, selecione Aceitar. Se você for um administrador, marque a caixa de seleção ao lado de Consentimento em nome da sua organização para que outros usuários não vejam esse prompt. Selecione Concluído. Se você encontrar um pop-up sobre cookies sendo desabilitados ou a página de login não carregar, ajuste suas configurações para aceitar cookies. Talvez seja necessário digitar a senha do seu e-mail. Digite sua senha e selecione Entrar. No Windows, você pode ser solicitado a adicionar uma exceção de segurança. Selecione Confirmar exceção de segurança. Você verá uma confirmação quando sua conta for adicionada com sucesso ao Thunderbird. Selecione Concluir.

content: If you want to synchronize messages between two PCs (or PC and smartphone) you should use the IMAP protocol an both. If on your work computer (POP) in Account Settings > Server Settings you keep the standard setting for leaving the messages on server "For at most 14 days" they will be deleted from the server after two weeks. Since an IMAP account shows only messages on the server you can still see messages in your POP account Inbox because they are stored locally, whereas they are no longer displayed in your IMAP account Inbox.

content: The junk feature is often assumed to be a whitelist/blacklist function, but it is not. Marking a message from a sender as junk does not place the sender into a blacklist, as Thunderbird uses an algorithm to detect junk. I suggest a thorough review of the article at https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages One of the requirements to effectively train the junk controls is to routinely mark both junk and non-junk. Some users also use third-party software, such as Mailwasher, to assist in that.

creator: mpjdonovan

content:
6.3 GB is too big a size for an Inbox folder - respectively the correspondant Inbox mailbox file in the TB profile ! This is the folder which suffers most of the message traffic and therefore most likely can get damaged. Ideally its size should turn around some hundred MB and to maintain a rather small size one should delete messages without importance and archive messages one wants to keep- or has to keep for legal reasons.

I prescribe a weight loss diet for your Inbox folder. Delete as many messages as you can and archive most of the rest, e. g. in the Local Folders by creating thematic folders. When this is done compact the Inbox via R-click > Compact ...

After deleting all unnecessary messages you may compact the Inbox a first time and test whether TB still freezes (gets unresponsive). If TB is revived you may take more time to set up an archive for your important messages later when it suits you.
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thank you. How do I access the contents of the Inbox folder? TB won't load it and it crashes the program when I try. Is there a utility program to access and edit the contents?
creator: mpjdonovan

content:
mpjdonovan said
Thank you. How do I access the contents of the Inbox folder? TB won't load it and it crashes the program when I try.

OK, we must change our strategy. Does TB crash immediately on startup? As long as TB is still responsive go to Settings > General > Disk Space: click on "Clear Now", then go to Indexing and uncheck "Enable Global Search and Indexer".

If this doesn't work, open the TB profile folder following this description https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_finding-your-profile-without-opening-thunderbird In the profile folder search for rhe file global-messages-db.sqlite and delete it. Then open the subfolder "Mail", open the account folder pop.xxx.xx and delete the file Inbox.msf. On restart TB will take some time to rebuild the Inbox.msf and the global-messages-db.sqlite files (you can follow progress in the left corner of the status bar).

If TB still hangs, force-quit the application. Go again to the Profile folder > Mail > pop.xxx.xx, rename the big Inbox file to Inbox-1 and delete the Inbox.msf file. This manipulation neutralizes the big Inbox and and on restart forces Thunderbird to create a new Inbox which will download the messages still being on the server!

By this manipulation at least you should get a Thunderbird which no longer becomes unresponsive. But there still is the fate of the big Inbox which seems to be damaged and the question how to recover all the messages stored in it. [If you had a Mac or Linux PC it would be easy to cut the big Inbox file into smaller Mbox files of 1 GB or 500 MB each by a simple command line in the Terminal] There are Mbox-Breaker tools in the Internet, some free for smaller files or paying for big GB files. I can't test them because I have a Mac.

You could also open the big Inbox file in a text editor and cut it manually in two or three or more smaller mbox files (copy & paste method). For this manipulation you need to download a very strong text editor since the usual Windows editors are too weak.

creator: davidsk

content:
There is nothing unsupportive in my tone or substance. I am trying to help you.

If your address book (and apparently your e-mail account, if that is where the scam messages are coming from) was hacked, there is nothing that anyone associated with Mozilla or Thunderbird or this community support forum can do about it. You must work with your e-mail provider.

Mozilla and Thunderbird are not e-mail providers. Sky seems to be your e-mail provider.

I cannot pass you on to anyone. This is a forum where users support each other. I am a user, not an employee.

What would you like to accomplish with settings in Thunderbird? Something to do with your address book? Something to do with scam messages? Do you have reason to believe that your messages are being moved because of settings? Do you use mail filters?

Rick

content:
t.mullins said
They say which seems to make sense is that although I have a sky email address, it is you as my email provider that should know where your email preferences should be found in Settings and how to assist me. Please pass me on to someone that can assist. If its not your company

Your email provider is the one after the @ in your email address, in this case it is sky.com

There are two ways you can view your email. You can use a email client (like Thunderbird) to view your emails on your computer or a phone/tablet. Or you can use a web browser like Firefox to view your email at you email providers webmail (aka web based email) site and in this case for sky it is https://skyid.sky.com/signin/email which seems to be a form of Yahoo email.

https://www.sky.com/help/articles/getting-started-with-sky-yahoo-mail

content:
To ensure that all PCs are always in sync, all accounts must be IMAP, no exceptions. Once you have one PC set the way you like, you can copy the profile and place on the other two. That, of course, does not include synchronizing Local Folders for the very reason that they're local. To copy a profile, follow these steps:

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is not running on old PC
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

TIP: Save the external media copy for backup.
creator: davidsk

content: Sorry, Local folders are just that, local. However, depending on how you reinstalled, I encourage looking in profiles folder to see if there is an older profile that has the folders you seek. I can't advise on Macs, but in windows, the profiles are in the appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder.

content:
Oi, para diagnosticar problemas com o Thunderbird, tente uma das seguintes opções:

  • Reinicie o Thunderbird com os complementos desabilitados (Modo Thunderbird Seguro). No menu Ajuda, clique em "Reiniciar com os complementos desativados". Se o Thunderbird funciona normal, há um problema com algum complemento ou tema. Você vai precisar reativar os complementos, um de cada vez, até localizar o infrator.
  • Reinicie o sistema operacional em modo de segurança com rede. Isso carrega apenas o básico necessário para iniciar o computador, permitindo uma ligação à Internet. Clique no seu sistema operacional para obter instruções sobre como iniciar em modo de segurança: Windows 8, Windows 7, Windows Vista, Windows XP, OSX
Se o modo de segurança do sistema operacional corrige o problema, há outro software em seu computador que está causando problemas. As possibilidades incluem, mas não limitados: a digitalização AV, vírus / malwares, downloads em segundo plano, como atualizações do programa.

content:
looks to me like you may well have an issue with an antivirus program. Have you added an exception for the Thunderbird profile folder to your antivirus. They tend to make a mess of many things.

If you sent mail is in gmail or outlook sent folders simply disable the function to save copies in Thunderbird and both these providers save copies of outgoing mail to the send folder and this can exacerbate antivurs issues as Thunderbird and the server both change the folder at about the same time.

Of not any search involving number can be expected to fail. Any search involving the quoted text in an email will fail as quoted text is not indexed at all. Searches involving words of three or less characters will fail. Again not indexed.

creator: Lokimeister

content:
Hi Lokimeister,

We all have good intentions here and are doing our best to help each other.

I suggest these steps:

1. For each folder that you want to be able to search, including "Trash", right click on the folder name, select "Properties", and click on "Include messages in this folder in the Global Search results"m then "OK". Indexing will take a little time if your folders are big or many. The Activity Manager should tell you when the indexing for each folder is done.

2. Try your typical searches and note the results.

3. Let us know your search terms and how well the searches worked.

Rick
creator: user213815874572776100201782415079883066567

content:
Thank you.

So under Properties, the folder in question was indeed not set up for indexing.  ?? In any case, is there any additional benefit of repairing the folder or is this the same process as reindexing?
creator: Lokimeister

content:
You're welcome.

I am not an expert on indexing, but the index that repairing a folder re-creates is different from the global search index, so I don't think that there is a relationship here. I believe that repairing is helpful when, e.g., messages are not appearing in the list of messages because an index specific to that folder is corrupt.
